title: Information About Other Players in Mechanism Design

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We show the existence of mechanism design settings where the planner has an interest in agents receiving noisy signals about the types of other agents. When the planner is interested only in partial implementation - designing a mechanism for which there exists an equilibrium that yields a desired outcome - any social choice rule that is incentive-compatible after agents receive additional information about other agents is incentive-compatible without this information. However, additional information about other agents can eliminate undesired equilibria, making it helpful to a planner interested in full implementation - designing a mechanism for which every equilibrium outcome is desirable. We provide a sufficient condition under which a social choice rule that is not fully implementable when agents have no information about types of other agents can become fully implementable if agents have additional information.

## 1 Introduction

The goal of a social planner in any mechanism design problem is to design a game under which a desirable outcome emerges in equilibrium. In implementation theory, agents have private information consisting of their own preferences over a set of outcomes as well as information about the preferences of other agents. Naturally, the set of equilibrium outcomes that can emerge from a mechanism is sensitive to the details of the information available to agents. A considerable body of mechanism design literature focuses on the effects of changing information structures on achieving desirable outcomes. Most of this work focuses on how much agents know about variables that directly affect their own payoffs - for example, the information a bidder knows about her own valuation for an object (Bergemann et al. (2022)) - rather than information about other agents' preferences.

In this paper, we examine how the planner can have an interest in agents possessing additional information about the preferences of other agents, revisiting the Bayesian implementation problem as studied by Jackson (1991), as well as Postlewaite and Schmeidler (1986) and Palfrey and Srivastava (1989). In this setting, agents fully understand their own preferences over a set of outcomes but do not know the preferences of other agents. Agents' beliefs about the preferences of other agents are drawn from a common prior, which will be

[^0]
[^0]:    *This article subsumes my undergraduate thesis at Harvard University. I am indebted to my thesis advisor Eric Maskin for constant and invaluable guidance and Stephen Morris for generous discussions, as well as Michal Kowalik, Shengwu Li, Matthew Rabin, Madison Shirazi, and Charlie Yang for helpful comments.

assumed to have full support. This paper additionally supposes that agents can receive a full-support signal regarding the preferences of other agents. The model, which is explained in section 2, considers how the implementability of a social choice function (SCF) changes as the information structure varies. The question is whether and when there exist SCFs that are not implementable when agents have no information about the types of other agents but are implementable when one or more agents receive additional information about other agents.

This question can be asked with respect to either partial or full implementation. Partial implementation requires only that the planner's desired outcome is achieved by some equilibrium of the game, while full implementation demands that every equilibrium of the game yields a desirable outcome. It is well-known that the partial implementability of an SCF depends only on whether it satisfies incentive compatibility, which requires that it is a best response for an agent to behave truthfully if all other agents are behaving truthfully. In section 3, we show that any SCF which satisfies incentive compatibility when agents receive informative signals about the types of other agents also satisfies incentive compatibility when agents do not have this additional information. This implies that a planner concerned only with partial implementation will never prefer an agent to have additional information about other agents. The reason is when an agent has access to an informative signal about the preferences of other agents, the planner must ensure that the agent is incentivized to report truthfully in each signal realization. However, a weighted average of these constraints across signal realizations yields the incentive constraint needed for the agent if she did not have access to additional information, making this latter constraint easier to satisfy.

The remainder of the paper shows how additional information about the types of other agents can help an agent signal to the planner that an undesirable equilibrium is being played, which is relevant if the planner is concerned with full implementation. In section 4 we present the main example of the paper: an SCF that is not fully implementable when agents do not have access to informative signals about the preferences of other agents but is fully implementable when agents have access to a sufficiently accurate signal about other agents. The condition that rules out undesired equilibria in Bayesian implementation settings is Bayesian monotonicity, which guarantees that agents have sufficient incentives to signal to the planner that an undesirable equilibrium strategy is being played. Much of this paper examines how Bayesian monotonicity varies with the information agents have about other agents. Section 5 presents a sufficient condition under which an SCF that is not fully implementable when agents have no information about the types of other agents becomes fully implementable under a more informative information structure.

An obvious concern with endowing an agent with additional information about the pref-

erences of other agents is that it can affect their own incentive to report truthfully to the mechanism. Indeed, the conclusion of section 3 is that incentive compatibility becomes harder to satisfy as agents receive additional information about other agents. To simplify the analysis, this paper focuses on the effects of modifying the beliefs of agents with dominant strategies. In both the main example and the general results, informative signals about other agents are only accessed by agents for which truth-telling is already a dominant strategy. This prevents the elimination of the planner's desired equilibrium outcome after the agents receive informative signals about the types of other agents and focuses the analysis on how additional information can allow an agent to signal undesirable deviations to the planner.

The signal we construct - in order to incentivize an agent $i$ to report to the planner that a specific untruthful equilibrium is being played - relies on a partition of the set of types of agents other than $i$ into two groups and informs agent $i$, with a sufficiently high degree of accuracy, whether the realized types of other agents belong to one group or the other. The intuition of this partition construction is the following: Each group should contain a type profile of other agents such that if the agent $i$ knew this type profile realized, she would prefer all other agents report truthfully rather than misreport according to the untruthful equilibrium, regardless of her own type. If agent $i$ is confident enough that the realized type profile is in one of these groups, she can propose an alternate SCF that swaps the outcomes implemented under the truthful strategy versus the untruthful strategy. By construction, this alternate SCF can only give agent $i$ a weakly lower payoff relative to the original if all other agents report truthfully, so agent $i$ would only propose it if an untruthful strategy profile is being played. Agent $i$ will have an incentive to propose this alternate SCF whenever the signal is sufficiently accurate.

Though a planner may want, for the goal of full implementation, agents to have access to informative signals about the types of other agents compared to no information, a key point of the analysis is that the planner does not always prefer a more informative signal structure. In particular, the signals constructed do not accurately inform any agent of the exact type profiles of other agents. One can imagine many reason why such a signal structure would be ineffective. For example, if there is a type profile of other agents such that all types of an agent $i$ would prefer play an untruthful equilibrium strategy as opposed to a truthful one, there will be no way to incentivize agent $i$ to report the untruthful equilibrium to the planner if she is sufficiently confident that this undesirable type profile has been realized. The conclusion that a designer may prefer information structures that are more informative, but not too much more informative, is consistent with the rapidly growing literature on information design spurred by Rayo and Segal (2010) and Kamenica and Gentzkow (2011). Thorough reviews of recent advancements in information design can be found in Bergemann and Morris (2019)

and Kamenica (2019).

Related Literature This paper most directly contributes to the literature on full Bayesian implementation, which began with Postlewaite and Schmeidler (1986), Palfrey and Srivastava (1989), and Jackson (1991). This paper also adds to the extensive literature on the effect of changing information structures in mechanism design settings pioneered by Bergemann and Välimäki (2002). It relates especially to the literature on information disclosure in mechanism design. In auction settings, Ganuza (2004) studies the optimal way for a seller to disclose a costly public signal about a good's characteristic in a second-price auction, which is a component of bidders' private valuations, while Bergemann and Pesendorfer (2007) investigate the joint design problem in which the seller controls the information bidders have about their own valuations and the auction rules. Other papers that have investigated the effects of information disclosure in auction settings include Esô and Szentes (2007), and Bergemann et al. (2022). Similar questions have also been investigated in screening settings by Li and Shi (2017) and Roesler and Szentes (2017). As previously stated, much of the current literature focuses on how much agents know about their own preferences. This thesis focuses on a mechanism designer's interest in agents knowing about other agents. Additionally, unlike the auction papers that portray the auctioneer as having the ability to provide information to agents, this thesis remains agnostic on where the information about other agents comes from. The emphasis is on how changing information structures can affect the planner's implementation goals. Finally, while our paper asks whether a planner can be interested in agents' information about other agents, one can also ask about an agent's incentives to acquire such information, as done in Gleyze and Pernoud (2023), who show that most economically meaningfully mechanisms cannot prevent an agent who has the option of acquiring information about her own type as well as types of other agents from choosing to acquire information about other agents.

# 2 Model 

There is a set of agents $I=\{1, \ldots, n\}$ such that $n \geq 3$, outcomes $A$, and a state $\theta \in \Theta$ taking the form $\theta=\left(\theta_{1}, \ldots, \theta_{n}\right)$. Each $\theta_{i}$ is the payoff type (henceforth type) of agent $i$. The set of possible types for agent $i$ is denoted $\Theta_{i}$, so $\Theta=\Theta_{1} \times \cdots \times \Theta_{n}$. There is a full support common prior $\mu$ over $\Theta$. Each agent $i$ knows her own type $\theta_{i}$ but may not be able to determine $\theta_{-i}=\left(\theta_{1}, \ldots, \theta_{i-1}, \theta_{i+1}, \ldots, \theta_{n}\right)$. Write $\Theta_{-i}=\prod_{j \neq i} \Theta_{j}$. Each agent $i \in N$ has a utility function that depends only on $\Theta_{i}$, so $u_{i}: A \times \Theta_{i} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$. Thus, for every type $\theta_{i} \in \Theta_{i}$, agent $i$ has a set of preferences over the outcomes in $A$. This is the case of private values.

Write $a \succcurlyeq_{\theta_{i}} b$ if $u_{i}\left(a, \theta_{i}\right) \geq u_{i}\left(b, \theta_{i}\right)$ and $a \succ_{\theta_{i}} b$ if $u_{i}\left(a, \theta_{i}\right)>u_{i}\left(b, \theta_{i}\right)$. Similarly define the notation $\preccurlyeq$ and $\prec$.

The planner wishes to implement a social choice function (SCF) $F: \Theta \rightarrow A$. The planner commits to a mechanism $\Gamma=\langle M, h\rangle$, such that $M=\prod_{i=1}^{n} M_{i}$ consists of a message space $M_{i}$ for each agent $i$ and $h: M \rightarrow A$ is the outcome function. A strategy profile $s=\left(s_{1}, \ldots, s_{n}\right)$ specifies for each agent $i$ a function $s_{i}: \Theta_{i} \rightarrow M_{i}$. At any state $\theta$, let $s(\theta)=\left(s_{1}\left(\theta_{1}\right), \ldots, s\left(\theta_{n}\right)\right)$ be the message profile sent by all agents, and $s_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)=\left(s_{j}\left(\theta_{j}\right)\right)_{j \neq i}$ denote the messages sent by agents other than $i$. Let $B^{\Gamma}$ be the set of Bayesian Nash equilibria for a mechanism $\Gamma$. If there is a $s \in B^{\Gamma}$ such that $h \circ s=F$ then $\Gamma$ partially implements $F$, and $F$ is considered partially implementable. If $\Gamma$ partially implements $F$, and $B^{\Gamma}$ contains only one equilibrium outcome, then $\Gamma$ fully implements $F$ and $F$ is considered fully implementable.

Classical mechanism design results pin down two key conditions for the implementability of an SCF $F$ in Bayesian settings.

Definition 1. An SCF $F$ is incentive-compatible if and only if for all agents $i$ and all $\theta_{i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{i}$,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{i}, \theta_{-i}\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}\right) \geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i}\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}\right)
$$

where the expectation is taken over the belief of type $\theta_{i}$ about $\Theta_{-i}$.
From the revelation principle we know that an SCF $F$ is partially implementable iff $F$ is incentive-compatible. For an incentive-compatible $F$ to be fully implementable, it must also satisfy Bayesian monotonicity, as studied by Postlewaite and Schmeidler (1986); Palfrey and Srivastava (1989); Jackson (1991).

Definition 2. A deception for agent $i$ is a function $\alpha_{i}: \Theta_{i} \rightarrow \Theta_{i}$. A deception $\alpha=$ $\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}\right)$ consists of a deception $\alpha_{i}$ for each agent $i \in N$.

Definition 3. Let $\alpha$ be a deception and

$$
\alpha(\theta)=\left(\alpha_{1}\left(\theta_{1}\right), \ldots, \alpha_{n}\left(\theta_{n}\right)\right)
$$

and

$$
\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)=\left(\alpha_{1}\left(\theta_{1}\right), \ldots, \alpha_{i-1}\left(\theta_{i-1}\right), \alpha_{i+1}\left(\theta_{i+1}\right), \ldots, \alpha_{n}\left(\theta_{n}\right)\right)
$$

An SCF F satisfies Bayesian monotonicity if for all deceptions $\alpha$ such that $F \circ \alpha \neq F$ there is an agent $i$ and a function $y: \Theta_{-i} \rightarrow A$ such that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}\right) \geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y\left(\theta_{-i}\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}\right)
$$

for all $\theta_{i} \in \Theta_{i}$ and

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right)\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right)<\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right)
$$

for some $\theta_{i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{i}$.
It was shown in Jackson (1991) that incentive compatibility and Bayesian monotonicity are necessary and sufficient for an SCF $F$ to be fully implementable in economic environments with at least 3 agents. ${ }^{12}$ While incentive compatibility guarantees that truth-telling is an equilibrium of the direct mechanism, Bayesian monotonicity is the condition that allows the planner to design a mechanism that can eliminate undesired equilibria. The key intuition behind this condition is as follows. Suppose agents are initially at an equilibrium that uses a deception $\alpha$ such that $F \circ \alpha \neq F$. By allowing any individual agent $i$ to specify an alternate SCF (the function $y$ can be extended to $\Theta$ by implementing the same outcome regardless of agent $i$ 's type) that is implemented only if it appears to harm agent $i$, an agent can choose to use this alternate SCF to signal to the planner that the agents are lying. Upon seeing the alternate SCF, the planner understands that a deception is being played because it would harm agent $i$ in a truth-telling equilibrium, regardless of her own type. Bayesian monotonicity gives at least one type of agent $i$ an incentive to specify an alternate SCF because she would prefer the alternate SCF to $F$ under the deception $\alpha$, ruling out the deception as an equilibrium. Bayesian monotonicity guarantees that such a procedure can be done for every undesirable deception.

The beliefs agents have regarding the types of other agents is an important component of both incentive compatibility and Bayesian monotonicity. We study how these conditions change when agents have additional information about the types of other agents.

Suppose each agent $i$ can access a signal

$$
\sigma_{i}: \Theta_{-i} \rightarrow \Delta\left(\zeta_{i}\right)
$$

where $\zeta_{i}$ is a finite set of signal realizations and $\sigma_{i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)$ is the signal observed by agent $i$ when the type profile of other agents is $\theta_{-i}$. The notation $\Delta\left(\zeta_{i}\right)$ denotes probability distributions over $\zeta_{i}$. Assume that $\sigma_{i}$ has full support over $\zeta_{i}$ for every agent $i$. After observing the realization of $\sigma_{i}$ and her type $\theta_{i}$, agent $i$ updates her beliefs regarding $\Theta_{-i}$ (and $\Theta$ ) according to Bayes' rule. In particular, suppose $\zeta_{i}=\left\{A_{i 1}, \ldots, A_{i k}\right\}$ and agent $i$ has type $\theta_{i}$. Upon

observing $\sigma_{i}=A_{i j}$, agent $i$ places probability

$$
\mu\left(\theta_{-i} \mid \theta_{i}, \sigma_{i}=A_{i j}\right)=\frac{\mu\left(\theta_{-i} \mid \theta_{i}\right) \sigma_{i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\left(A_{i j}\right)}{\sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime}} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}\right) \sigma_{i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right)\left(A_{i j}\right)}

Figure 1. Mechanism timing.

When the signals $\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ provide no information, the model is equivalent to the classical Bayesian implementation problem studied by Jackson (1991). The main question we address is whether and when an SCF $F$ that is not partially (resp. fully) implementable when $\sigma_{i}$ is noninformative for all $i$ can become partially (resp. fully) if one or more of the $\sigma_{i}$ is nontrivial. We are agnostic on where the signals $\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ come from. The nature of the question is one of comparative statics on the implementability of an SCF $F$ with respect to an increase in information one more agents $i$ has regarding $\Theta_{-i}{ }^{3}$ In the remainder of this paper we will say that $F$ is partially implementable with respect to $\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ if truth-telling is an equilibrium in the direct mechanism in each realization of the signals $\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$. Similarly define fully implementable with respect to $\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$. Note that when agents receive a signal $\sigma_{i}$ about other agents, both $\theta_{i}$ and $\sigma_{i}$ are both part of agent $i$ 's private information, so if $\sigma_{i}$ has possible realizations in $\zeta_{i}=\left\{A_{i 1}, \ldots, A_{i k}\right\}$ an implementing mechanism should ask each agent $i$ to specify a strategy for each $\left(\theta_{i}, A_{i j}\right)$ pair. Our setup is implicitly analyzing an equivalent formulation of this mechanism in which the uncertainty coming from the signals $\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}$ is resolved first and asking whether $F$ is partially or fully implementable in each "interim game" of the full mechanism.

We make several substantive assumptions that simplify and clarify the analysis. Other than requiring all $\sigma_{i}$ to have full support, we assume there are no restrictions over the structure of the signal agent $i$ can receive. Thus, agents do not have private information that can constrain the types of signals they can process. Additionally, we assume the signals are not costly in order to focus on the role of the additional information regarding other agents' types. Finally, the structure of the signals $\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ is assumed to be common knowledge.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{3}$ Since agents initially do not have any information about $\Theta_{-i}$ aside from the common prior $\mu$, any nontrivial signal $\sigma_{i}$ represents an increase in agent $i$ 's information with respect to the Blackwell order.

# 2.1 The full-support signal assumption 

To justify the assumption that each $\sigma_{i}$ has full support, it is helpful to consider the following example. Suppose the environment consists of three agents $i=1,2,3$, where each agent $i$ has types $\theta_{i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}$. There is a uniform common prior, so all states are equally likely. There are 5 possible outcomes $A=\{a, b, c, d, e\}$. The SCF $F$ is as follows.

![table_0](table_0)


![table_1](table_1)

This notation specifies $F$ by separating the types of agent 1 along rows, agent 2's types along columns, and agent 3's types along the left versus right boxes. For example, $F\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \theta_{3}\right)=a$ while $F\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)=c$. The agents have the following preferences.

![table_2](table_2)

Further, suppose agent 1's VNM utility function $u_{1}$ is such that:

$$
u_{1}\left(a, \theta_{1}\right)=3, u_{1}\left(b, \theta_{1}\right)=2, u_{1}\left(c, \theta_{1}\right)=0
$$

and

$$
u_{1}\left(c, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)=3, u_{1}\left(b, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)=1, u_{1}\left(a, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)=0
$$

Then $F$ does not satisfy incentive compatibility in this information structure, since

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right)=\frac{3}{2}<\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right)=\frac{7}{4}
$$

and

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)=\frac{5}{4}<\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)=\frac{3}{2}
$$

If $\sigma_{i}$ is uninformative for all $i$, it follows that $F$ is not fully or partially implementable under the specified information structure. On the other hand, if $\sigma_{i}$ is perfectly informative for all $i$, each agent $i$ has complete information regarding the state $\theta$ upon observing the

realization of $\sigma_{i}$ and learning their own type $\theta_{i}$. In this case, the problem becomes the classical Nash implementation problem solved by Maskin (1999), which shows that Maskin monotonicity ${ }^{4}$ and no veto power ${ }^{5}$ are sufficient conditions for the full implementability of $F$ when there are at least three agents. No veto power is automatically satisfied because $F$ never allows two agents to simultaneously get their most preferred outcome. To see that $F$ is Maskin-monotonic, first note that outcomes $a$ and $c$ fall relative to each other in agent 3's preference ranking when moving between types $\theta_{3}$ and $\theta_{3}^{\prime}$ and vice versa. Additionally, $b$ falls relative to $a$ in agent 1's preference ranking when moving from type $\theta_{1}^{\prime}$ to $\theta_{1}$, and $a$ and $c$ both fall relative to $d$ when agent 1 moves from type $\theta_{1}$ to $\theta_{1}^{\prime}$. Finally, $a$ and $c$ fall relative to each other in agent 2's preference ranking when moving between types $\theta_{2}$ and $\theta_{2}^{\prime}$ and vice versa, and $b$ falls relative to $a$ and $c$ when moving from $\theta_{2}^{\prime}$ to $\theta_{2}$. Thus $F$ is implementable if each $\sigma_{i}$ provides agent $i$ with a perfect signal regarding $\Theta_{-i}$.

This example demonstrates that agents receiving information about the preferences of others can allow an initially non-implementable SCF to become implementable, a possibility that has not yet been noted in the literature. It also shows how the incentive compatibility condition changes when agents are able to completely rule out certain states of the world. In particular, since implementation with complete information is a special case of Bayesian implementation, it must be that $F$ satisfies incentive compatibility under complete information even though it is not incentive-compatible under the uniform common prior. This is because an agent's type $\theta_{i}$ encapsulates information about both the preferences of agent $i$ and the information she has about the types of other agents. In the example above, $\theta_{i}$ is a complete description of agent $i$ 's type under the uniform common prior, because it specifies her preferences over the outcomes but she is not able to rule out any type profile of the other agents. Under complete information, however, $\theta_{i}$ is no longer an adequate description of her type. Since agent $i$ is able to completely discern the types of the other agents, her type includes what she knows to be the type profile of the other agents. As such, if one were to translate the example above with complete information into the Bayesian implementation setup, then $\Theta_{i}=\prod_{j=1}^{3}\left\{\theta_{j}, \theta_{j}^{\prime}\right\}$ for all $i$. So, when agent $i$ has preferences according to $\theta_{i}$, she has four corresponding types $t_{i} \in \Theta_{i}$. This is consistent with the mechanism exhibited in Maskin (1999), where each agent was asked to report the complete state of the world, which included information about the preferences of all agents.

In the translation of a complete information implementation problem into one of Bayesian implementation, the states $\Theta=\prod_{i} \Theta_{i}$ contain many zero-probability states. In fact, any

$t=\left(t_{1}, t_{2}, t_{3}\right) \in \Theta$ for which each $t_{1}=t_{2}=t_{3}$ does not hold is a state that occurs with zero probability. However, the planner still specifies the SCF for these events in order to preclude equilibria that are deceptions. This renders the incentive compatibility condition trivial when $n \geq 3$, because if one agent unilaterally deviates from the truth, the planner can simply ignore the deviation and implement the outcome in the state reported by $n-1$ agents. ${ }^{6}$ As such, the restriction that each $\sigma_{i}$ always has full support simply prevents changes to any type space $\Theta_{i}$ after agents receive the signal realization.

sections.text:
# 3 Partial implementation and the direct mechanism 

In this section we show that providing additional information to agents about the types of other agents is not helpful for the planner interested only in the partial implementation of an SCF. In our framework, this means that if $F$ is not implementable with respect to an uninformative signal structure, then it is not implementable with respect to any signal structure $\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$. For the remainder of this paper, write $\phi_{i}$ to mean an uninformative signal about $\Theta_{-i}$ for each $i$.

Given any SCF $F$ we can consider the direct mechanism defined by $\Gamma_{F}=\langle M, h\rangle$, where $M_{i}=\Theta_{i}$ for each $i$ and $h=F$. Each agent $i$ has a truth-telling strategy $s: \Theta_{i} \rightarrow \Theta_{i}$ given by $s\left(\theta_{i}\right)=\theta_{i}$. The revelation principle says that $F$ is partially implementable with respect to $\left\{\phi_{i}\right\}$ iff truth-telling for all agents is a Nash equilibrium of the direct mechanism. This is equivalent to incentive compatibility, which for the noninformative information structure $\left\{\phi_{i}\right\}$ means that for each agent $i \in I$ and $\theta_{i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{i}$,

$$
\sum_{\theta_{-i} \in \Theta_{-i}} \mu\left(\theta_{-i} \mid \theta_{i}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{i}, \theta_{-i}\right), \theta_{i}\right) \geq \sum_{\theta_{-i} \in \Theta_{-i}} \mu\left(\theta_{-i} \mid \theta_{i}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i}\right), \theta_{i}\right)
$$

If, however, $\sigma_{i} \in\left\{A_{i 1}, \ldots, A_{i k}\right\}$ contained information about $\Theta_{-i}$, partial implementation requires $F$ to be incentive-compatible with respect to the beliefs of agent $i$ in every realization of $\sigma_{i}$. In other words, for every $1 \leq \ell \leq k$ it must be that

$$
\sum_{\theta_{-i} \in \Theta_{-i}} \mu\left(\theta_{-i} \mid \theta_{i}, \sigma_{i}=A_{\ell}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{i}, \theta_{-i}\right), \theta_{i}\right) \geq \sum_{\theta_{-i} \in \Theta_{-i}} \mu\left(\theta_{-i} \mid \theta_{i}, \sigma_{i}=A_{\ell}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i}\right), \theta_{i}\right)
$$

The law of total expectations implies that (i) is just a weighted average of the equations (ii) for $1 \leq \ell \leq k$. This implies the following proposition.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{6}$ This opens up the possibility of undesired equilibria, which are ruled out by Maskin monotonicity. The Bayesian monotonicity condition reduces to Maskin monotonicity in complete information environments.

Proposition 1. Suppose $F$ is an SCF that is partially implementable with respect to some signal structure $\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$. Then $F$ is partially implementable with respect to $\left\{\phi_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$.

In other words, it can only become harder for $F$ to satisfy incentive compatibility if an agent receives an informative signal about other agents' types, compared to the no information case. We wish to avoid ruling out the equilibrium specified by $F$ while making certain agents' information structures more informative. Thus for the remainder of this paper we focus on the information of agents for which truth-telling is a dominant strategy in the direct mechanism.

It is well-known that the direct mechanism generally has undesired equilibria. The mechanism exhibited by Jackson (1991) to fully implement an SCF $F$ allows each agent to report, among other information, an alternate SCF that can be used to signal a deception to the planner, provided $F$ is Bayesian monotonic. In this paper, it will be useful to keep track of which agents have an incentive to alert the planner of a given deception, so we introduce the following notion.

Definition 4. Let $F$ be an SCF and $\alpha$ be a deception such that $F \circ \alpha \neq F$. Say that $\alpha$ is undermined by agent $i$ (or agent $i$ undermines $\alpha$ ) if there is a function $y: \Theta_{-i} \rightarrow A$ such that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}\right) \geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y\left(\theta_{-i}\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}\right)
$$

for all $\theta_{i} \in \Theta_{i}$ and

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right)\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right)<\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right)
$$

for some $\theta_{i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{i}$.
The inequalities are exactly the ones from the definition of Bayesian monotonicity. Since a deception is equivalent to a strategy profile in the direct mechanism, the only deceptions $\alpha$ such that $F \circ \alpha \neq F$ that need to be undermined in order to guarantee the full implementation of $F$ are (untruthful) equilibria of the direct mechanism. For any incentive-compatible SCF $F$, write $\mathcal{A}_{F}$ to be the set of deceptions $\alpha$ such that $F \circ \alpha \neq F$ and constitute an equilibrium of the direct mechanism when agents do not have additional information about other agents. Let $\mathcal{A}_{F}^{u} \subset \mathcal{A}_{F}$ be the set of deceptions that can be undermined by some agent $i$, again when agents have no additional information about other agents. Then we have the following.

Lemma 1. Let $F$ be an incentive-compatible SCF. In economic environments, $F$ is fully implementable if and only if $\mathcal{A}_{F}^{u}=\mathcal{A}_{F}$.

The lemma is a direct implication of the full Bayesian implementation result of Jackson (1991) but will prove useful in our general results.

# 4 Main example 

In this section we exhibit an SCF that is not fully implementable with respect to $\left\{\phi_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ but is fully implementable with respect to some informative signal structure $\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$. The key constraint considered in this section is Bayesian monotonicity. In particular, we show how a signal about the types of other agents can incentivize an agent to alert the planner of a deception, which the agent would not have an incentive to do without this information.

The environment has 3 agents, who each have two types, drawn non-independently from a full-support common prior over the eight possible agent type profiles. Under the planner's desired SCF, which we will first show is incentive-compatible, there are two agents who each have an incentive to misreport her type given that the other is as well. Therefore, there is an equilibrium of the direct mechanism in which these two agents are simultaneously deceiving. Next we show that this equilibrium arises from a deception that violates Bayesian monotonicity, implying that any mechanism that partially implements the SCF will have this undesirable equilibrium. Thus the SCF is not fully implementable when agents have no additional information about other agents' types. However, there is a third agent for which truth-telling is a dominant strategy. We show that increasing the information she has about the types of the other two agents incentivizes her to alert the planner about this deception, implying that the SCF can satisfy Bayesian monotonicity under a more informative information structure. Finally, we show that this modification to the third agent's information allows the SCF to become fully implementable.

We now present the example formally, which will illustrate the main points of the general result. Suppose the environment consists of three agents $i=1,2,3$, where each agent $i$ has types $\theta_{i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}$. There are 6 possible outcomes $A=\{a, b, c, d, e, f\}$. The SCF $F$ is as follows.

![table_3](table_3)


![table_4](table_4)

The agents have the following preferences over $A$.

![table_5](table_5)

Each agent is indifferent between two outcomes and has strict preferences over the others. The numbers in parentheses represent the utilities of each type of each agent from the outcomes.

Let $\mu$ be the common prior on $\Theta$ that places $1 / 6$ probability on each of the type profiles $\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \cdot\right),\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}, \cdot\right)$, and places $1 / 3$ probability on each of the type profiles $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}, \cdot\right)$ and $\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}, \cdot\right)$. Independently, each of the type profiles $\left(\cdot, \cdot, \theta_{3}\right),\left(\cdot, \cdot, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)$ has a $1 / 2$ probability. In other words, the type of agent 3 is independent of the types of agents 1 and 2 , but type $\theta_{1}$ of agent 1 infers $1: 2$ odds of agent 2 being type $\theta_{2}$ vs. type $\theta_{2}^{\prime}$, while type $\theta_{1}^{\prime}$ of agent 1 infers $2: 1$ odds of agent 2 being type $\theta_{2}$ vs. type $\theta_{2}^{\prime}$.

The outcome $f$ exists to make this environment economic, so incentive compatibility and Bayesian monotonicity are necessary and sufficient for full implementation.

The claim is that $F$ is partially but not fully implementable with respect to $\left\{\tau_{i}\right\}$ if $\tau_{i}$ is the uninformative signal for all $i$. In particular $F$ is incentive-compatible, but there is a deception that creates a violation of Bayesian monotonicity, meaning that it cannot be ruled out by any mechanism.

sections.text:
# 4.1 Incentive compatibility 

To see that $F$ is incentive-compatible, truth-telling is must be an equilibrium of the direct mechanism. For agent 1 , observe

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right)=\frac{1}{3} u_{1}\left(a, \theta_{1}\right)+\frac{1}{3} u_{1}\left(b, \theta_{1}\right)+\frac{1}{3} u_{1}\left(c, \theta_{1}\right)=10 / 3 \\
\geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right)=\frac{1}{3} u_{1}\left(e, \theta_{1}\right)+\frac{2}{3} u_{1}\left(d, \theta_{1}\right)=19 / 6
\end{gathered}
$$

Similarly,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)=10 / 3 \geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)=19 / 6
$$

Therefore, the incentive compatibility constraint holds for agent 1. A similar argument shows the incentive compatibility constraint holds for agent 2. For agent 3, truth-telling is a dominant strategy, as type $\theta_{3}$ strictly prefers outcome $b$ to $c$ while type $\theta_{3}^{\prime}$ strictly prefers outcome $c$ to $b$. Thus, $F$ is incentive-compatible.

# 4.2 Bayesian monotonicity 

To show that $F$ is partially but not fully implementable, we need to exhibit a deception $\alpha$ such that $F \circ \alpha \neq F$ that violates Bayesian monotonicty. We claim that $\alpha=$ $\left(\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}\right),\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{3}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)\right)$ creates a violation of Bayesian monotonicity. In order for this to be true, it must be an equilibrium of the direct mechanism but fail the Bayesian monotonicity constraint described above. To see that $\alpha$ is an undesired equilibrium of the direct mechanism, suppose agent 1 deviates to $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}\right)$. Then type $\theta_{2}$ of agent 2 gets an expected payoff of

$$
\frac{2}{3} u_{2}\left(a, \theta_{2}\right)+\frac{1}{3} u_{2}\left(e, \theta_{2}\right)=8 / 3
$$

from truth-telling and an expected payoff of

$$
\frac{1}{3} u_{2}\left(b, \theta_{2}\right)+\frac{1}{3} u_{2}\left(c, \theta_{2}\right)+\frac{1}{3} u_{2}\left(d, \theta_{2}\right)=10 / 3
$$

from deceiving to $\theta_{2}^{\prime}$, so the best response of type $\theta_{2}$ is to deceive. Similarly type $\theta_{2}^{\prime}$ will deceive to $\theta_{2}$. Thus $\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right)$ is agent 2's best response to $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}\right)$. Similarly, $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}\right)$ is agent 1's best response to $\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right)$. It follows that $\alpha=\left(\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}\right),\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{3}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)\right)$ is an undesired equilibrium in the direct mechanism.

It remains to show that $\alpha$ violates Bayesian monotonicity, implying that agents 1 and 2 will always have an incentive to simultaneously deceive in any incentive-compatible mechanism. Recall that $F$ satisfies Bayesian monotonicity iff for all deceptions $\alpha$ such that $F \circ \alpha \neq F$ there exist $i \in I$ and a function $y: \Theta_{-i} \rightarrow A$ such that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}\right) \geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y\left(\theta_{-i}\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}\right)
$$

for all $\theta_{i} \in \Theta_{i}$ and

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right)\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right)<\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right)
$$

for some $\theta_{i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{i}$.
It needs to be shown that for no agent $i$ does there exist an alternate SCF $y$ with the

desired properties. First consider agent 1. In order to define a $y: \Theta_{-1} \rightarrow A$ such that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(y\left(\alpha_{-1}\left(\theta_{-1}\right)\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right)>\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}\right)\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right)
$$

it must be that (1) $y\left(\theta_{2}, \cdot\right)=e, y\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \cdot\right) \succeq_{\theta_{1}} d$, and at least one of $y\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{3}\right) \succeq_{\theta_{1}} b, c$ or $y\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right) \succeq_{\theta_{1}} b, c$ holds, or (2) the following inequalities hold.

$$
u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{3}\right), \theta_{1}\right)+u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{1}\right)<11
$$

and

$$
u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{3}\right), \theta_{1}\right)+u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{1}\right)>4
$$

If (1) applies, compute that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{-1}\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right) \geq \frac{21}{6}>\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right)=\frac{10}{3}
$$

which is not a valid alternate SCF $y$. Now, suppose (2) applies. Let

$$
A=u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{3}\right), \theta_{1}\right)+u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{1}\right)
$$

and

$$
B=u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{3}\right), \theta_{1}\right)+u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{1}\right)
$$

Then case (2) says that $A<11$ and $B>4$. Given the utility specifications for agent 1 , it follows that $A \leq 9.5$ and $B \geq 5$. Observe that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(y\left(\alpha_{-1}\left(\theta_{-1}\right)\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right)>\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}\right)\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right) \Rightarrow 2 A+B>26
$$

and

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right) \geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{-1}\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right) \Rightarrow A+2 B \leq 20
$$

From here it is easy to see that there are no solutions to both inequalities satisfying $A \leq 9.5$ and $B \geq 5$. By similar reasoning, there is no $y: \Theta_{-1} \rightarrow A$ such that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(y\left(\alpha_{-1}\left(\theta_{-1}\right)\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)>\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)
$$

and

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)<\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{-1}\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)
$$

Thus, agent 1 cannot undermine $\alpha$. For agent 2 , the utility experienced from outcome $f$ is

too high for her to include it as a possible outcome in any alternate SCF $y$. Thus, similar reasoning as what was provided for agent 1 shows that agent 2 also cannot undermine $\alpha$. For agent 3 , note that her expected utility for truth-telling versus the deception $\alpha$ will always be the same, no matter what the SCF is. Therefore, the expected utility for agent 3 in the specified SCF is the same for truth-telling versus the deception $\alpha$, and similarly for any alternate SCF $y$. It follows that agent 3 can't profit from signaling the deception via an alternate SCF unless she profits from the alternate SCF without deception as well, so agnet 3 cannot undermine $\alpha .{ }^{7}$ Therefore $F$ is not fully implementable if no agents receive informative signals about the types of other agents.

# 4.3 Eliminating $\alpha$ as an equilibrium 

We claim that there is a binary signal that agent 3 can receive regarding the types of agents 1 and 2 that allows $F$ to satisfy Bayesian monotonicity and as result become fully implementable. Suppose $\sigma_{3} \in\{0,1\}$ is such that

$$
P\left(\sigma_{3}=0 \mid \theta_{-3}=\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right)\right)=P\left(\sigma_{3}=0 \mid \theta_{-3}=\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right)\right)=2 / 3
$$

and

$$
P\left(\sigma_{3}=1 \mid \theta_{-3}=\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)\right)=P\left(\sigma_{3}=1 \mid \theta_{-3}=\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)\right)=2 / 3
$$

If $\sigma_{3}=0$, then agent 3 's updated beliefs place $2 / 9$ probability on both $\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right)$ and $\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)$, $1 / 9$ probability on $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)$, and $4 / 9$ probability on $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right)$. If $\sigma_{3}=1$, then agent 3 's updated beliefs place $1 / 9$ probability on $\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right), 2 / 9$ probability on both $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right)$ and $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)$, and $4 / 9$ probability on $\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)$.

Since showing that none of the $\alpha_{i}$ for $1 \leq i \leq 5$ violate Bayesian monotonicity did not require any information about agent 3's beliefs, and the signal agent 3 receives modifies only her beliefs, it suffices to consider only the deviation $\alpha$ when showing that $F$ satisfies Bayesian monotonicity. Note that $F$ needs to satisfy Bayesian monotonicity in either realization of $\sigma_{3}$.

First suppose $\sigma_{3}=0$. Define $y: \Theta_{-3} \rightarrow A$ by $y\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right)=d, y\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)=b, y\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right)=e$, and $y\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)=a$. Then

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(F\left(\theta_{-3}, \theta_{3}\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)=\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(a, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(b, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{4}{9} u_{3}\left(e, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{1}{9} u_{3}\left(d, \theta_{3}\right)=32 / 9
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{7}$ This property may appear to render this example a knife-edge case, but we show in Appendix A that this example can be modified in a straightforward way to remove its reliance on agent 3's indifference. For now, agent 3's indifference allows the example to be somewhat simpler and focus on the effect of an additional signal.

$$
\geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(y\left(\theta_{-3}\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)=\frac{1}{9} u_{3}\left(a, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(b, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{4}{9} u_{3}\left(e, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(d, \theta_{3}\right)=29 / 9
$$

and

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(F\left(\theta_{-3}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)=32 / 9 \geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(y\left(\theta_{-3}\right), \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)=23 / 9
$$

but

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-3}, \theta_{3}\right)\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)=\frac{1}{9} u_{3}\left(a, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{4}{9} u_{3}\left(b, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(e, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(d, \theta_{3}\right)=31 / 9 \\
& <\mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(y\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-3}\right)\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)=\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(a, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{4}{9} u_{3}\left(b, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(e, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{1}{9} u_{3}\left(d, \theta_{3}\right)=34 / 9
\end{aligned}
$$

Now suppose $\sigma_{3}=1$. Define $y: \Theta_{-3} \rightarrow A$ by $y\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right)=a, y\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)=e, y\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right)=$ $b, y\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)=d$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(F\left(\theta_{-3}, \theta_{3}\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)=\frac{1}{9} u_{3}\left(a, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{4}{9} u_{3}\left(b, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(e, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(d, \theta_{3}\right)=31 / 9 \\
& \geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(y\left(\theta_{-3}, \theta_{3}\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)=\frac{1}{9} u_{3}\left(a, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(b, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{4}{9} u_{3}\left(e, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(d, \theta_{3}\right)=29 / 9
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(F\left(\theta_{-3}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)=31 / 9 \geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(y\left(\theta_{-3}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)=23 / 9
$$

But

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-3}, \theta_{3}\right), \theta_{3}\right)\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)=\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(a, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(b, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{4}{9} u_{3}\left(e, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{1}{9} u_{3}\left(d, \theta_{3}\right)=32 / 9 \\
& <\mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(y\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-3}, \theta_{3}\right), \theta_{3}\right)\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)=\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(a, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{4}{9} u_{3}\left(b, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{2}{9} u_{3}\left(e, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{1}{9} u_{3}\left(d, \theta_{3}\right)=34 / 9
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, upon receiving the signal $\sigma_{3}$, agent 3 can undermine $\alpha$. The intuition of the signal construction is as follows. For $F$ as described, truth-telling is a dominant strategy for agent 3. Additionally, agent 3 always prefers that agent 1 and 2's type profile is $\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right)$ rather than $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)$, regardless of her type. Suppose agent 3 is quite confident that agent 2 is type $\theta_{2}$, so she believes it is more likely that the type profile of agents 1 and 2 belongs to $\left\{\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right)\right\}$ rather than $\left\{\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)\right\}$. In particular, suppose she is confident enough that she places a higher probability on $\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right)$ than $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)$. Then, under the SCF $F$, if the deception $\alpha$ is being played, she believes it is more likely that her utility will be harmed by agents $\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right)$ deviating to $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)$, than benefited by the vice versa happening. It is therefore beneficial for her to propose the alternate SCF $y: \Theta_{-3} \rightarrow A$, which is defined by $y\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right)=d, y\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)=b, y\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right)=e$, and $y\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)=a$, that swaps the outcomes for the type profiles $\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right)$ and $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)$ while holding the outcomes for the other type profiles

constant. Similarly, agent 3 prefers that agent 1 and 2's type profile is $\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)$ rather than $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right)$. If agent 3 is quite confident that the type profile of agents 1 and 2 belongs to $\left\{\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)\right\}$, then if the deception $\alpha$ is being played with the SCF $F$, she will believe it is more likely that her utility will be harmed by agents $\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)$ deviating to $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right)$ than benefited by the vice versa happening. Thus, swapping the outcomes in these cases by proposing the alternate SCF $y: \Theta_{-3} \rightarrow A$ defined by $y\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right)=a, y\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)=e, y\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right)=b$, and $y\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)=d$ allows her undermine $\alpha$.

# 4.4 Full implementability of $F$ 

We want to conclude that $F$ is implementable with respect to $\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}_{i \in\{1,2,3\}}$ where $\sigma_{1}, \sigma_{2}$ are uninformative and $\sigma_{3}$ is as specified above. To do so, we will analyze the equilibria of the direct mechanism for $F$ under this modified information structure for agent 3 and apply lemma 1.

It was shown above that truth-telling and $\alpha$ were equilibria of the direct mechanism under the uninformative information structure. It is straightforward to verify that these equilibria are unchanged in either realization of $\sigma_{3}$. The other equilibria of the direct mechanism, in either realization of $\sigma_{3}$, are the following: $\alpha_{1}=\left(\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{3}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)\right), \alpha_{2}=$ $\left(\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{1}\right),\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{3}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)\right), \alpha_{3}=\left(\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{3}^{\prime}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)\right), \alpha_{4}=\left(\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{3}^{\prime}, \theta_{3}\right)\right)$, and $\alpha_{5}=\left(\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{3}, \theta_{3}\right)\right)$.

To see this, suppose agent 1 deviates to $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)$. Since both types of agent 2 prefer $e$ to $d$, agent 2 's best response is $\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{2}\right)$. Both types of agent 1 prefer $e$ to $a$, so $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)$ is also a best response to $\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{2}\right)$. Thus $\alpha_{1}=\left(\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{3}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)\right)$ is an undesired equilibrium in the direct mechanism. Similarly, if agent 1 deviates to $\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{1}\right)$, both types of agent 2 prefer $b$ or $c$ to $a$, so agent 2 's best response is $\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)$. Since both types of agent 1 prefer $b$ or $c$ to $d$, agent 1 's best response is $\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{1}\right)$, so $\alpha_{2}=\left(\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{1}\right),\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{3}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)\right)$ is another undesired equilibrium in the direct mechanism. Finally, since agent 3 's report only affects the outcome of the direct mechanism if agent 1 reports $\theta_{1}$ and agent 2 reports $\theta_{2}^{\prime}$, it follows that $\alpha_{3}=$ $\left(\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{3}^{\prime}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)\right), \alpha_{4}=\left(\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{3}^{\prime}, \theta_{3}\right)\right)$, and $\alpha_{5}=\left(\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{3}, \theta_{3}\right)\right)$ are all undesired equilibria, in either realization of $\sigma_{3}$. Truth-telling, $\alpha, \alpha_{1}, \alpha_{2}, \alpha_{3}, \alpha_{4}$, and $\alpha_{5}$ cover all possible strategies for agent 1 in the direct mechanism. Since they are all equilibria and truth-telling is a dominant strategy for agent 3 (a property that is independent of $\sigma_{3}$ 's realization), there can be no other equilibria in the direct mechanism, in either realization of $\sigma_{3}$.

We claim that each deception $\alpha_{i}$ for $1 \leq i \leq 5$ can be undermined by either agent 1 or agent 2 . To see this, first note that all such deceptions make the expected utility of agents 1 and 2 certain, since agents 1 and 2 are not sending different messages for different realizations

of their own type. Moreover, in no case does a deception $\alpha_{i}$ allow all types of agents 1 and 2 to for sure get their most preferred outcome. This makes it easy for the agents to define an alternate SCF that would benefit them. For example, in the case of $\alpha_{1}$, consider the function $y: \Theta_{-1} \rightarrow A$ defined by $y\left(\theta_{2}, \cdot\right)=d, y\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \cdot\right)=f$. Then

$$
E\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right)=10 / 3 \geq E\left(u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{-1}\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right)=4 / 3
$$

and

$$
E\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)=10 / 3 \geq E\left(u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{-1}\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)=3
$$

but

$$
E\left(u_{1}\left(y\left(\alpha_{1}\left(\theta_{-1}\right)\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)=4>E\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\alpha_{1}\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)=3
$$

It follows that $\alpha_{1}$ is undermined by agent 1 . Similar arguments show that $\alpha_{2}, \alpha_{3}, \alpha_{4}$, and $\alpha_{5}$ are also undermined. Since $\sigma_{3}$ only affects the information of agent 3 , each $\alpha_{i}$ for $1 \leq i \leq 5$ can be undermined by either agent 1 or agent 2 in both realizations of $\sigma_{3}$. In the previous subsection we saw that agent 3 can undermine $\alpha$ in either realization of $\sigma_{3}$. Therefore, lemma 1 implies that $F$ is fully implementable with respect to $\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}_{i \in\{1,2,3\}}$.

This example also illustrates how a planner can strictly prefer agents to have an information structure that is between no information and complete information. Indeed, $F$ is also not fully implementable in a complete information environment because it fails Maskin monotonicity: when moving from the state $\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}, \theta_{3}\right)$ to $\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \theta_{3}\right)$, the outcome $e$ is chosen in the former state and weakly rises in every agent's preference ordering, but $e$ is not chosen in the latter state.

# 5 General results 

The main example suggests how an agent for which truth-telling is a dominant strategy for a given SCF $F$ can undermine a given deception $\alpha$ with additional information about the types of other agents, in a way that she would not be able to do so without this information. In particular, suppose $F$ is an SCF such that there is a type profile $\theta_{-i}^{\prime}$ that yields an outcome agent $i$ prefers to that of the type profiles in $\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right)$, regardless of what agent $i$ reports. Suppose additionally that agent $i$ believes $\theta_{-i}^{\prime}$ is more likely to be the true type profile of other agents than the type profiles in $\alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right)$. Then it is possible for some type $\theta_{i}$ of agent $i$ to undermine $\alpha$ by proposing the alternate SCF that swaps the outcomes corresponding to $\theta_{-i}^{\prime}$ and $\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right)$ assuming she plays $\alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)$. Thus, if agent $i$ can receive a signal that ensures such a type profile $\theta_{-i}^{\prime}$ always exists, then an undesirable equilibrium $\alpha$ can be potentially undermined. We formalized this into the following condition.

Definition 5. Let $F$ be an $S C F$ and $\alpha \in \mathcal{A}_{F}$. Agent $i$ can potentially undermine $\alpha$ if truth-telling is a dominant strategy for agent $i$ and there exist distinct type profiles $\theta_{-i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i}^{\prime \prime}$ such that $\alpha_{-i}\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right)\right) \neq \theta_{-i}^{\prime \prime}, \alpha_{-i}\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime \prime}\right)\right) \neq \theta_{-i}^{\prime}, \alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right) \neq \alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime \prime}\right)$ and the inequalities

$$
\begin{aligned}
& u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \geq u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \\
& u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime \prime}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \geq u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime \prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

hold for all $\theta_{i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{i}$. Furthermore the inequalities are strict for some type $\theta_{i}^{\prime}=\theta_{i}$.
The inequalities capture the intuition that agent $i$ should always prefer other agents report truthfully rather than according to the deception $\alpha$ if she knew the type profiles $\theta_{-i}^{\prime}$ or $\theta_{-i}^{\prime \prime}$ realized. This preference needs to be strict for at least one type of agent $i$ in order to provide sufficient incentives for her to deviate from the undesirable equilibrium $\alpha$. The requirements that $\alpha_{-i}\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right)\right) \neq \theta_{-i}^{\prime \prime}, \alpha_{-i}\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime \prime}\right)\right) \neq \theta_{-i}^{\prime}$, and $\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right) \neq \alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime \prime}\right)$, limit the interactions $\theta_{-i}^{\prime}$ and $\theta_{-i}^{\prime \prime}$ have with each other in the deception $\alpha$, which allows us to partition the type space $\Theta_{-i}$ in a natural way. As the name suggests, an agent $i$ that can potentially undermine a deception $\alpha$ can undermine $\alpha$ with additional information about the types of other agents. In other words, we have the following lemma, which is the main technical contribution of this paper.

Lemma 2. Let $F$ be an incentive-compatible $S C F \alpha$ be a deception that agent $i$ can potentially undermine. Then there is a binary signal $\sigma_{i}: \Theta_{-i} \rightarrow \Delta(\{0,1\})$ such that agent $i$ can undermine $\alpha$ after receiving either realization of $\sigma_{i}$.

In particular, for $\theta_{-i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i}^{\prime \prime}$ as in Definition 5, the signal informs agent $i$, with sufficiently high accuracy, whether or not the type profile of other agents is in the set

$$
\left\{\theta_{-i}^{\prime}, \alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime \prime}\right)\right\} \cup \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right)
$$

The full proof is given in Appendix B. For an incentive-compatible $F$ that is not fully implementable, the lemma suggests a systematic way to eliminate all deceptions in $\mathcal{A}_{F} \backslash \mathcal{A}_{F}^{n}$ (which must be non-empty by lemma 1) with additional information. In particular, we have the following result.

Theorem 1. Let $F$ be an incentive-compatible SCF. If there is a subset $J \subset I$ such that each $\alpha \in \mathcal{A}_{F} \backslash \mathcal{A}_{F}^{n}$ can be potentially undermined by a distinct agent $j \in J$, and every $\alpha \in \mathcal{A}_{F}^{n}$ can be undermined by some agent $i \in I \backslash J$, then $F$ is fully implementable with respect to some signal structure $\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$.

The result is essentially a straightforward application of lemmas 1 and 2, and the proof is in the appendix. The theorem requires a separation of the agents who can undermine deceptions in $\mathcal{A}_{F}^{n}$ from the agents who can potentially undermine deceptions in $\mathcal{A}_{F} \backslash \mathcal{A}_{F}^{n}$ because we cannot guarantee that an agent who undermines a deception $\alpha \in \mathcal{A}_{F}^{n}$ without additional information can still undermine $\alpha$ after receiving an informative signal about other agents. This implicitly requires $\left|\mathcal{A}_{F} \backslash \mathcal{A}_{F}^{n}\right| \leq n-1$.

# 6 Conclusion 

The main finding of the paper is that increasing the information agents have about the types of other agents can serve to eliminate undesired equilibria in full implementation problems. Consequently, there are social choice rules that are not originally fully implementable under a given information structure but become fully implementable after agents receive noisy signals about the types of other agents. We provide a sufficient condition that guarantees the existence of a more informative information structure that can allow an SCF $F$ that is not fully implementable under some full-support common prior to become fully implementable. We conclude by discussing some limitations of the analysis.

The results are dependent on the specifics of agents' beliefs in different information structures. In particular, given a non-fully-implementable SCF, any increase in information agents have about the types of other agents would need to be common knowledge for there to potentially exist a mechanism that fully implements the SCF under the new information structure. While these assumptions are standard in the implementation literature, a recent strand of literature in mechanism design focuses on the robustness of mechanisms (pioneered by Bergemann and Morris (2005)), arguing that mechanism design should not rely excessively on common knowledge assumptions among the agents and the planner. The dependence on common knowledge assumptions is certainly a limitation on the results presented, but it is worth noting the main finding - that increasing information an agent has about other agents can eliminate undesired equilibria - does not depend on a single, specific change in information. Rather, in every example and theorem presented, the signal an agent receives that eliminates an undesired equilibrium is simply required to be above a certain level of accuracy. In all of the examples and results presented, whenever a signal $\sigma$ of accuracy $0.5<\tau<1$ eliminates an undesired equilibrium, any signal with the same realizations but higher accuracy $\tau^{\prime}>\tau$ also eliminates the equilibrium. Thus, while the agents do need to fully understand when other agents have received additional information, the exact accuracy of the signals received does not need to be known.

# A Appendix A: A more robust example 

In the example provided in section 4, agent 3 is indifferent between the truth-telling equilibrium and the deception $\alpha$ regardless of the social choice rule, raising the question of whether it is simply describing a knife-edge case. But the example can be modified to accommodate this concern.

There are still three agents $i=1,2,3$, where each agent $i$ has types $\theta_{i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}$, and 6 possible outcomes $A=\{a, b, c, d, e, f\}$. The SCF $F$ remains the same, as follows.

![table_6](table_6)


![table_7](table_7)

Modify the agents' preferences to get the following.

![table_8](table_8)

Modify the common prior $\mu$ to be defined by

$$
\mu\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \cdot\right)=1 / 10, \mu\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}, \cdot\right)=3 / 10, \mu\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}, \cdot\right)=9 / 20, \mu\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}, \cdot\right)=3 / 20
$$

Moreover, the type of agent 3 is independent of the types of agents 1 and 2 , and $\mu\left(\cdot, \cdot, \theta_{3}\right)=$ $\mu\left(\cdot, \cdot, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)=1 / 2$.

We follow similar steps as in the main example to show that $F$ is incentive-compatible and that the direct mechanism contains the equilibria $\alpha=\left(\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}\right),\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{3}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)\right), \alpha_{1}=$ $\left(\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{3}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)\right), \alpha_{2}=\left(\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{1}\right),\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{3}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)\right), \alpha_{3}=\left(\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{3}^{\prime}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)\right), \alpha_{4}=$ $\left(\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{3}^{\prime}, \theta_{3}\right)\right)$, and $\alpha_{5}=\left(\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right),\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{2}\right),\left(\theta_{3}, \theta_{3}\right)\right)$. It is also analogous to show that all of the $\alpha_{i}$ for $1 \leq i \leq 5$ can be undermined by agents 1 and 2 .

The deception $\alpha$ still violates Bayesian monotonicity under the specified common prior, meaning that no agent can undermine $\alpha$. As before, first consider agent 1. In order to define a $y: \Theta_{-1} \rightarrow A$ such that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(y\left(\alpha_{-1}\left(\theta_{-1}\right)\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right)>\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\alpha_{-1}\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}\right)\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right)
$$

it must be that (1) $y\left(\theta_{2}, \cdot\right)=e, y\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \cdot\right) \succeq_{\theta_{1}} d$, and at least one of $y\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{3}\right) \succeq_{\theta_{1}} b, c$ or $y\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right) \succeq_{\theta_{1}} b, c$ holds; (2) $y\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{3}\right)=e, y\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)=a$ and $y\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \cdot\right) \succeq_{\theta_{1}} b, c$; or (3) $y\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{3}\right)=a$, $y\left(\theta_{2}, \theta_{3}^{\prime}\right)=e$ and $y\left(\theta_{2}^{\prime}, \cdot\right) \succeq_{\theta_{1}} b, c$. If (1) applies, compute that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{-1}\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right) \geq \frac{27}{8}>\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right)=\frac{13}{4}
$$

which is not a valid alternate SCF $y$. If any of the other cases apply, it must also be that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right)<\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{-1}\right), \theta_{1}\right) \mid \theta_{1}\right)
$$

By similar reasoning, in order to define a $y: \Theta_{-1} \rightarrow A$ such that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(y\left(\alpha_{-1}\left(\theta_{-1}\right)\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)>\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)
$$

it must also be that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(F\left(\theta_{-1}, \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)<\mathbb{E}\left(u_{1}\left(y\left(\theta_{-1}\right), \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{1}^{\prime}\right)
$$

Thus agent 1 cannot undermine $\alpha$. For agent 2 , the utility experienced from outcome $f$ is again too high for her to include it as a possible outcome in any alternate SCF $y$, so agent 2 cannot undermine $\alpha$. Since agent 3 is no longer indifferent between $\alpha$ and truth-telling, it remains to show that no $y: \Theta_{-3} \rightarrow A$ exists that makes $F$ Bayesian monotonic. Note that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(F\left(\theta_{-3}, \theta_{3}\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)=\frac{1}{10} u_{3}\left(a, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{3}{10} u_{3}\left(b, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{9}{20} u_{3}\left(e, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{3}{20} u_{3}\left(d, \theta_{3}\right)
$$

while

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-3}, \theta_{3}\right)\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)=\frac{3}{20} u_{3}\left(a, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{9}{20} u_{3}\left(b, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{3}{10} u_{3}\left(e, \theta_{3}\right)+\frac{1}{10} u_{3}\left(d, \theta_{3}\right)
$$

Then there are 2 ways to define a $y: \Theta_{-3} \rightarrow A$ to get

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(y\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-3}\right)\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)>\mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-3}, \theta_{3}\right)\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)
$$

An alternate SCF $y$ must either satisfy (1) $y\left(\theta_{1}, \cdot\right)=a$ and $y\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \cdot\right) \in\{d, e\}$ or (2) $y\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right) \succ_{\theta_{3}}$ $d, e$ or $y\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right) \succ_{\theta_{3}} d, e$. If (1) applies, it is clear that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(F\left(\theta_{-3}, \theta_{3}\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)<\mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(y\left(\theta_{-3}\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)
$$

Now suppose (2) applies. Then in order for

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(F\left(\theta_{-3}, \theta_{3}\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right) \geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(y\left(\theta_{-3}\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)
$$

it must be that

$$
\begin{gathered}
u_{3}\left(a, \theta_{3}\right)+3 u_{3}\left(b, \theta_{3}\right)-u_{3}\left(y\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right), \theta_{3}\right)-3 u_{3}\left(y\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{3}\right) \\
\geq \frac{3}{2}\left(3 u_{3}\left(y\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right), \theta_{3}\right)+u_{3}\left(y\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{3}\right)-3 u_{3}\left(e, \theta_{3}\right)-u_{3}\left(d, \theta_{3}\right)\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

On the other hand, for

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(y\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-3}\right)\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)>\mathbb{E}\left(u_{3}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-3}, \theta_{3}\right)\right), \theta_{3}\right) \mid \theta_{3}\right)
$$

to hold, it must be that

$$
\begin{gathered}
3 u_{3}\left(y\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right), \theta_{3}\right)+u_{3}\left(y\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{3}\right)-3 u_{3}\left(e, \theta_{3}\right)-u_{3}\left(d, \theta_{3}\right) \\
>\frac{3}{2}\left(u_{3}\left(a, \theta_{3}\right)+3 u_{3}\left(b, \theta_{3}\right)-u_{3}\left(y\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right), \theta_{3}\right)-3 u_{3}\left(y\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{3}\right)\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

Since all quantities are positive, it is impossible for (iii) and (iv) to hold simultaneously. Thus there cannot be a $y: \Theta_{-3} \rightarrow A$ that allows $F$ to satisfy Bayesian monotonicity.

Similar reasoning as what was given in the main example implies the signal $\sigma_{3} \in\{0,1\}$ such that

$$
P\left(\sigma_{3}=0 \mid \theta_{-3}=\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}\right)\right)=P\left(\sigma_{3}=0 \mid \theta_{-3}=\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}\right)\right)=2 / 3
$$

and

$$
P\left(\sigma_{3}=1 \mid \theta_{-3}=\left(\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)\right)=P\left(\sigma_{3}=1 \mid \theta_{-3}=\left(\theta_{1}^{\prime}, \theta_{2}^{\prime}\right)\right)=2 / 3
$$

if accessed by agent 3 , allows $F$ to satisfy Bayesian monotonicity.
