# B Appendix B: Omitted proofs
## Proof of Proposition 1.

Proof. Fix a agent $j$. Since every agents' beliefs and every signal has full support, the only possible signal that affects agent $j$ 's expected payoff is $\sigma_{j}$. Suppose $\sigma_{j} \in\left\{A_{j 1}, \ldots, A_{j k}\right\}$ and let $q_{\ell}$ be the unconditional probability that $\sigma_{j}=A_{\ell}$ (so $q_{\ell}$ is averaged over all possible states).

If $F$ is incentive-compatible with respect to agent $j$ after agent $j$ receives this signal, then

$$
q_{\ell} \mathbb{E}\left(u_{j}\left(F\left(\theta_{-j}, \theta_{j}\right), \theta_{j}\right) \mid \theta_{j}, \sigma_{j}=A_{\ell}\right) \geq q_{\ell} \mathbb{E}\left(u_{j}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{j}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{j}\right) \mid \theta_{j}, \sigma_{j}=A_{\ell}\right)
$$

for all $1 \leq \ell \leq k$. By the law of iterated expectations,

$$
\sum_{\ell=1}^{k} q_{\ell} \mathbb{E}\left(u_{j}\left(F\left(\theta_{-j}, \theta_{j}\right), \theta_{j}\right) \mid \theta_{j}, \sigma_{j}=A_{\ell}\right)=\mathbb{E}\left(u_{j}\left(F\left(\theta_{-j}, \theta_{j}\right), \theta_{j}\right) \mid \theta_{j}\right)
$$

and

$$
\sum_{\ell=1}^{k} q_{\ell} \mathbb{E}\left(u_{j}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{j}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{j}\right) \mid \theta_{j}, \sigma_{j}=A_{\ell}\right)=\mathbb{E}\left(u_{j}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{j}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{j}\right) \mid \theta_{j}\right)
$$

Therefore, it must be that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{j}\left(F\left(\theta_{-j}, \theta_{j}\right), \theta_{j}\right) \mid \theta_{j}\right) \geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{j}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{j}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{j}\right) \mid \theta_{j}\right)
$$

so $F$ was incentive-compatible prior to agent $j$ receiving $\sigma_{j}$.

# Proof of Lemma 1. 

Proof. The only if direction is direct from the definitions. For the if direction, consider the following mechanism $\Gamma=\langle M, h\rangle$ to implement the SCF $F$. The mechanism, slightly adapted from Jackson (1991) to implement a single SCF $F$ rather than a set of SCFs, was shown to fully implement any SCF $F$ satisfying incentive compatibility and Bayesian monotonicity in economic environments. Let $S=\max _{i}\left|\Theta_{i}\right|$ and $K=n(S+1)$. Let $V=\left\{0,1, \ldots, S^{2}\right\}^{K}$, so $V$ consists of $K$-dimensional integer vectors with entries between 0 and $S^{2}$. Let $X$ be the space of all possible SCFs $F: \Theta \rightarrow A$. Let

$$
M_{i}=\Theta_{i} \times\{\{\varnothing\} \cup V\} \times X \times\{\{\varnothing\} \cup X\}
$$

For any message profile $m=\left(m_{1}, \ldots, m_{n}\right) \in M$, let $\theta^{m} \in \Theta$ be the type profile given by the first entry of every agent's message. The following rules specify $h$.

Rule 1: Suppose there is a $\operatorname{SCR} F \in \widehat{F}$ and $i \in N$ such that every $m_{j}$ for $j \neq i$ is of the form $(\cdot, \varnothing, \cdot, \varnothing)$. Additionally, $m_{i}$ is of the form $(\cdot, \varnothing, \cdot, \varnothing)$, or $(\cdot, \cdot, \cdot, \varnothing)$. Then $h(m)=F\left(\theta^{m}\right)$.

Rule 2: Suppose there is a $\operatorname{SCR} F \in \widehat{F}$ and $i \in N$ such that every $m_{j}$ for $j \neq i$ is of the form $(\cdot, \varnothing, \cdot, \varnothing)$. Additionally, $m_{i}$ is of the form $(\cdot, \cdot, \cdot, y)$ for some $y \in X$. Let $\theta_{i}$ be the first

entry of $m_{i}$, and define $y_{\theta_{i}} \in X$ by $y_{\theta_{i}}(\theta)=y\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}\right)$ for all $\theta \in \Theta$. Then

$$
h(m)= \begin{cases}y\left(\theta^{m}\right) & \text { if } \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y_{\theta_{i}}\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \text { for all } \theta_{i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{i} \\ F\left(\theta^{m}\right) & \text { if } \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y_{\theta_{i}}\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right)>\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \text { for some } \theta_{i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{i}\end{cases}
$$

Rule 3: Suppose neither rule 1 nor rule 2 applies. For $1 \leq k \leq 4$, let $m_{i}^{k}$ denote the $k$ th entry of the message of agent $i$. Then $h(m)=m_{i^{*}}^{3}\left(\theta^{m}\right)$, where $i^{*}$ is determined by the following. Let $I_{0}$ be the set of agents $i \in I$ that choose to specify an integer vector in their message, so $I_{0}=\left\{i \mid m_{i}^{2} \neq \varnothing\right\}$. For $i \in I_{0}$ denote $m_{i}^{2}$ by $v^{i}$, and let the $l$ th coordinate of the vector $v^{i}$ be $v_{l}^{j}$. Let

$$
J(i)=\#\left\{j \in I_{0} \mid v_{\ell}^{i}=v_{i}^{j} \text { for an integer } \ell \text { such that } n+(j-1) S<\ell \leq n+j S\right\}
$$

If there is $i$ such that $J(i)>J(k)$ for all $k \in I_{0}$ and $k \neq i$, then $i^{*}=i$. Otherwise, $i^{*}=\min _{i}\left(I_{0}\right)$.

Rules 2 and 3 ensure that in an equilibrium $s$ of $\Gamma$, Rule 1 must apply, as otherwise one agent can unilaterally deviate to get her most preferred outcome. If rule 1 applies and $s$ is an equilibrium of $\Gamma$, it must be the case that $\left(s_{i}^{*}\right)_{i \in I}$ - where $s_{i}^{*}\left(\theta_{i}\right)$ is the first coordinate of $s_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)$ for all $i$ and $\theta_{i} \in \Theta_{i}$ - is an equilibrium of the direct mechanism. Rule 2 ensures that $s=\left(s_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ where $s_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)$ is of the form $\left(\theta_{i}, \varnothing, \cdot, \varnothing\right)$ for all $i$ and $\theta_{i} \in \Theta_{i}$ is a BNE of $\Gamma$, so $\Gamma$ clearly partially implements $F$. If $\mathcal{A}_{F}=\mathcal{A}_{F}^{n}$ then rule 2 ensures that no $s$ such that $\left(s_{i}^{*}\right)_{i \in I}$ is an undesirable equilibrium of the direct mechanism constitutes an equilibrium of $\Gamma$. Thus $\Gamma$ fully implements $F$ whenever $\mathcal{A}_{F}=\mathcal{A}_{F}^{n}$.

# Proof of Lemma 2. 

Proof. Suppose agent $i$ can potentially undermine $\alpha$. Therefore truth-telling is a dominant strategy for agent $i$ and there exist a type $\theta_{i} \in \Theta_{i}$ as well as distinct type profiles $\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{2}, \theta_{-i}^{3}, \theta_{-i}^{4} \in \Theta_{-i}$ such that $\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}\right) \neq \theta_{-i}^{1}, \alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}\right) \neq \theta_{-i}^{3}$, and $\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{j}\right)=\theta_{-i}^{j+1}$ for $j=1,3$. Furthermore,

$$
u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{j}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \geq u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{j+1}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right)
$$

for $j=1,3$ and all $\theta_{i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{i}$, and the inequalities are strict for type $\theta_{i}^{\prime}=\theta_{i}$. Let $\sigma_{i} \in\{0,1\}$ be a binary signal such that if $\theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}\right\} \cup \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)$, then $P\left(\sigma_{i}=0 \mid \theta_{-i}\right)=\tau$ for some accuracy $0.5<\tau<1$. Additionally, if $\theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}\right\} \cup \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)$, then $P\left(\sigma_{i}=1 \mid \theta_{-i}\right)=\tau$. With slight abuse of notation we write $\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}$ to mean $\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}\right\} \cup \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)$. Since agent $i$ can potentially undermine $\alpha$, we have from the definition that $\left\{\alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}\right), \theta_{-i}^{2}, \theta_{-i}^{3}\right\} \subset$

$\Theta_{-i} \backslash\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}$. Thus, upon receiving $\sigma_{i}=0$, agent $i$ will place probability

$$
\tau \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right)
$$

on all $\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}$ and probability

$$
(1-\tau) \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right)
$$

on all $\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}$. Here $\mu\left(\cdot \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right)$ represents the beliefs agent $i$ would have over $\Theta_{-i}$ conditional on knowing her type is $\theta_{i}^{\prime}$, and the type profile $\theta_{-i}$ of other agents is in the set $\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}$. We will show that there exists an accurate enough $\tau$ such that agent $i$ can undermine $\alpha$.

To prove the lemma, $\alpha$ must be undermined by agent $i$ in either realization of the signal, so first suppose $\sigma_{i}=0$. Now let $y: \Theta_{-i} \rightarrow A$ be defined by $y\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}\right)=F\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), y\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}\right)=$ $F\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right)$, and $y\left(\theta_{-i}\right)=F\left(\theta_{-i}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right)$ for all $\theta_{-i} \neq \theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{2}$. This construction of $y$ is a general formulation of the alternate SCFs constructed for the main example. It first needs to be shown that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \sigma_{i}=0\right) \geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y\left(\theta_{-i}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \sigma_{i}=0\right)
$$

for all $\theta_{i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{i}$. To see this, observe that the following holds for sufficiently accurate $\tau$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \sigma_{i}=0\right)=\tau \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) \\
& \quad+(1-\tau) \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) \\
& \quad \geq \tau \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{1} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \\
& \quad+\tau \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{4} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \\
& \quad+\tau \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \\
& \quad+(1-\tau) \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{2} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \\
& \quad+(1-\tau) \sum_{\substack{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{-i} \backslash\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}}} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \\
& \geq \tau \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{1} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \\
& +\tau \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{4} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \\
& +\tau \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& +(1-\tau) \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{2} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \\
& +(1-\tau) \sum_{\substack{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{-i} \backslash\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y\left(\theta_{-i}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \sigma_{i}=0\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

as desired. The first inequality is implied by our assumption that agent $i$ always prefers $\theta_{-i}^{1}$ to $\theta_{-i}^{2}$ and holds whenever

$$
\tau \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{1} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) \geq(1-\tau) \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{2} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right)
$$

which can be done for sufficiently large $\tau$. The second inequality is because truth-telling is a dominant strategy for agent $i$. The last equality follows from the definition of $y$. Thus, the desired inequality holds.

It also needs to be shown that there is sufficiently large $\tau$ such that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}, \sigma_{i}=0\right)<\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}, \sigma_{i}=0\right)
$$

To see this, as before let $\alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}\right)$ be the (possibly empty) set of $\theta_{-i}$ such that $\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)=\theta_{-i}^{1}$. Note that our assumptions imply that $\alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}\right)$ is disjoint from $\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}$. So,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}, \sigma_{i}=0\right)=\tau \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{1} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& \quad+\tau \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{4} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}\right), \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& \quad+\tau \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& \quad+(1-\tau) \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& \quad+(1-\tau) \sum_{\substack{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \notin \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}\right)}} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right), \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) . \\
& \quad \text { Additionally, } \\
& \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right) \mid \theta_{i}, \sigma_{i}=0\right)=\tau \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{1} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& \quad+\tau \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{4} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}\right), \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& \quad+\tau \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& +(1-\tau) \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& +(1-\tau) \sum_{\substack{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \notin \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{1} \text { ) } \\
\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}}} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(y\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Comparing these expressions, first observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{\substack{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \notin \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right), \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& \left.\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right\} \\
& \leq \sum_{\substack{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \notin \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(y\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) . \\
& \theta_{-i}^{\prime} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

This is because the only possible $\theta_{-i}$ for which terms in the sum will differ are for $\theta_{-i} \in$ $\alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}\right)$ such that $\theta_{-i} \neq \theta_{-i}^{1}$. In the former summation, the corresponding term will be

$$
K_{2}=\mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right)
$$

The corresponding term in the latter summation, which is

$$
K_{1}=\mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right)
$$

If $\alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)=\theta_{i}$, then $K_{2}<K_{1}$ is automatic from the requirement that agent $i$ can potentially undermine $\alpha$. If $\alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right) \neq \theta_{i}$, then $u_{i}$ must satisfy

$$
u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right)=u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}, \theta_{i}\right), \theta_{i}\right)
$$

and

$$
u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right)=u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{i}\right), \theta_{i}\right)
$$

because truth-telling is a dominant strategy for agent $i$. Thus the assumption that agent $i$ can potentially undermine $\alpha$ also implies $K_{2}<K_{1}$.

Thus, to guarantee

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}, \sigma_{i}=0\right)<\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}, \sigma_{i}=0\right)
$$

it suffices to pick $\tau$ sufficiently large so that

$$
\begin{gathered}
\tau \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{1} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
+(1-\tau) \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
<\tau \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{1} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
+(1-\tau) \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{1}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

which is again possible by the condition that agent $i$ can potentially undermine $\alpha$ and similar reasoning as above. Thus $\alpha$ is undermined in the signal realization $\sigma_{i}=0$.

If the signal realization is $\sigma_{i}=1$, one can similarly define $y: \Theta_{-i} \rightarrow A$ by $y\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)=$ $F\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), y\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}\right)=F\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right)$, and $y\left(\theta_{-i}\right)=F\left(\theta_{-i}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right)$ for all $\theta_{-i} \neq \theta_{-i}^{3}, \theta_{-i}^{4}$. The proof that $\alpha$ is undermined in this case is largely analogous. To show that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \sigma_{i}=1\right) \geq \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y\left(\theta_{-i}\right), \theta_{i}^{\prime}\right) \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \sigma_{i}=1\right)
$$

for all $\theta_{i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{i}$, we can use similar steps as above to show that $\tau$ needs to satisfy

$$
\tau \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{3} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) \geq(1-\tau) \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{4} \mid \theta_{i}^{\prime}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right)
$$

for all $\theta_{i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{i}$.
Finally, one again needs to check that there is sufficiently large $\tau$ such that

$$
\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}, \sigma_{i}=1\right)<\mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}, \sigma_{i}=1\right)
$$

Observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-i}, \theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}, \sigma_{i}=1\right)=(1-\tau) \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{1} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& \quad+(1-\tau) \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{4} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}\right), \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& \quad+(1-\tau) \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& +\tau \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{1} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& +\tau \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \notin \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right), \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right), \\
& \theta_{-i}^{\prime} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

while

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}\left(u_{i}\left(y\left(\alpha\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mid \theta_{i}, \sigma_{i}=1\right)=(1-\tau) \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{1} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{2}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& \quad+(1-\tau) \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{4} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}\right), \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& \quad+(1-\tau) \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& +\tau \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& +\tau \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \notin \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\alpha_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime}\right), \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) . \\
& \theta_{-i}^{\prime} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

It therefore suffices to pick $\tau$ sufficiently large so that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& (1-\tau) \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& \quad+\tau \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& <(1-\tau) \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \in\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \\
& \quad+\tau \sum_{\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \in \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{4}\right)} \mu\left(\theta_{-i}^{\prime} \mid \theta_{i}, \theta_{-i} \notin\left\{\theta_{-i}^{1}, \theta_{-i}^{4}, \alpha_{-i}^{-1}\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}\right)\right\}\right) u_{i}\left(F\left(\theta_{-i}^{3}, \alpha_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

As before, this can be done with sufficiently large $\tau$. Thus, after agent $i$ receives the signal $\sigma_{i}$, she can undermine $\alpha$, and the proof is complete.

# Proof of Theorem 1. 

Proof. Let $\mathcal{A}_{F} \backslash \mathcal{A}_{F}^{n}=\left\{\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{k}\right\}$ and $j_{\ell}$ be the agent that can potentially undermine $\alpha_{\ell}$ for all $1 \leq \ell \leq k$. By lemma 2 , for each $\ell$ there is a binary signal $\sigma_{j_{\ell}}$ such that agent $j_{\ell}$ can undermine $\alpha_{\ell}$ upon receiving $\sigma_{j_{\ell}}$. By assumption each $j_{\ell}$ is distinct and $\left\{j_{1}, \ldots, j_{k}\right\} \subset J$. For all $i \in I \backslash\left\{j_{1}, \ldots, j_{k}\right\}$ let $\sigma_{i}$ be uninformative. Lemma 1 directly implies that $F$ is fully implementable with respect to these signals $\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ as long as the set of equilibria in the direct mechanism is unchanged after the agents $j_{1}, \ldots, j_{k}$ receive their signals. More precisely, if we take $\mathcal{B}_{F}$ to be the set of Bayes Nash equilibria of the direct mechanism when agents only know the common prior $\mu \in \Delta(\Theta)$, we want to show that $s \in \mathcal{B}_{F}$ if and only if $s$ is an equilibrium of the direct mechanism after the agents $j_{1}, \ldots, j_{k}$ receive their signals.

To see this, let $s=\left(s_{1}, \ldots, s_{n}\right)$ be a strategy profile. Then $s$ is an equilibrium in the direct mechanism when no agent has additional information about other agents iff for all $i$ and $\theta_{i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{i}$ we have

$$
\sum_{\theta_{-i}} u\left(F\left(s_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right), s_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mu\left(\theta_{-i} \mid \theta_{i}\right) \geq \sum_{\theta_{-i}} u\left(F\left(\theta_{i}^{\prime}, s_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mu\left(\theta_{-i} \mid \theta_{i}\right)
$$

On the other hand, $s$ is an equilibrium in the direct mechanism after agents receive the signal realizations $\left\{\sigma_{i}\right\}_{i \in I}$ iff for all $i \in I, \theta_{i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{i}$, and signal realizations $x$ in the range of $\sigma_{i}$, we have

$$
\sum_{\theta_{-i}} u\left(F\left(s_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right), s_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mu\left(\theta_{-i} \mid \theta_{i}, \sigma_{i}=x\right) \geq \sum_{\theta_{-i}} u\left(F\left(\theta_{i}^{\prime}, s_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \mu\left(\theta_{-i} \mid \theta_{i}, \sigma_{i}=x\right)
$$

When $i \notin\left\{j_{1}, \ldots, j_{k}\right\}$ the signal $\sigma_{i}$ is uninformative so the inequalities don't change between (v) and (vi). If $i \in\left\{j_{1}, \ldots, j_{k}\right\}$, then truth-telling is a dominant strategy for agent $i$, so it must be that

$$
u\left(F\left(\theta_{i}, s_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right) \geq u\left(F\left(\theta_{i}^{\prime}, s_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right)
$$

for all $\theta_{i}, \theta_{i}^{\prime} \in \Theta_{i}$, since $\mu$ and $\sigma_{i}$ have full support. Thus both (v) and (vi) are imply

$$
u\left(F\left(s_{i}\left(\theta_{i}\right), s_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right)=u\left(F\left(\theta_{i}, s_{-i}\left(\theta_{-i}\right)\right), \theta_{i}\right)
$$

for all $i \in\left\{j_{1}, \ldots, j_{k}\right\}$ and $\theta_{i} \in \Theta_{i}$. This completes the proof.

# References

_, Tibor Heumann, Stephen Morris, Constantine Sorokin, and Eyal Winter, "Optimal Information Disclosure in Classic Auctions," American Economic Review: Insights, September 2022, 4 (3), 371-388.

Esö, Péter and Balázs Szentes, "Optimal Information Disclosure in Auctions and the Handicap Auction," The Review of Economic Studies, 2007, 74 (3), 705-731. Publisher: [Oxford University Press, Review of Economic Studies, Ltd.].

abstract:
We show the existence of mechanism design settings where the planner has an
interest in agents receiving noisy signals about the types of other agents.
When the planner is interested only in partial implementation, any social
choice rule that is incentive-compatible after agents receive additional
information about other agents is incentive-compatible without this
information. However, additional information about other agents can eliminate
undesired equilibria, making it helpful to a planner interested in full
implementation. We provide a sufficient condition under which a social choice
rule that is not fully implementable when agents have no information about
types of other agents can become fully implementable if agents have additional
information.
